At the 1912 Salon d'Automne an architectural installation was exhibited that quickly became known as Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), signed Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare along with a group of collaborators. Metzinger and Gleizes in Du "Cubisme", written during the assemblage of the "Maison Cubiste", wrote about the autonomous nature of art, stressing the point that decorative considerations should not govern the spirit of art. Decorative work, to them, was the "antithesis of the picture". "The true picture" wrote Metzinger and Gleizes, "bears its raison d'être within itself. It can be moved from a church to a drawing-room, from a museum to a study. Essentially independent, necessarily complete, it need not immediately satisfy the mind: on the contrary, it should lead it, little by little, towards the fictitious depths in which the coordinative light resides. It does not harmonize with this or that ensemble; it harmonizes with things in general, with the universe: it is an organism...". "Mare's ensembles were accepted as frames for Cubist works because they allowed paintings and sculptures their independence", writes Christopher Green, "creating a play of contrasts, hence the involvement not only of Gleizes and Metzinger themselves, but of Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (Raymond Duchamp-Villon designed the facade) and Mare's old friends Léger and Roger La Fresnaye". Some rock musicians today use mandolins, often single-stringed electric models rather than double-stringed acoustic mandolins. One example is Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys. In addition to electric guitar, bass, and drums, the band uses several instruments associated with traditional Celtic music, including mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes. The band explains that these instruments accentuate the growling sound they favor. The 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" was driven by a few simple mandolin licks played by guitarist Peter Buck, who also played the mandolin in nearly a dozen other songs. The single peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart (#1 on the rock and alternative charts), Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes has made frequent use of the mandolin, most notably on the Black Crowes song "Locust Street." Armenian American rock group System of A Down makes extensive use of the mandolin on their 2005 double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize. Pop

President Truman, symbolizing a broad-based desire for an Eisenhower candidacy for president, again in 1951 pressed him to run for the office as a Democrat. It was at this time that Eisenhower voiced his disagreements with the Democratic party and declared himself and his family to be Republicans. A "Draft Eisenhower" movement in the Republican Party persuaded him to declare his candidacy in the 1952 presidential election to counter the candidacy of non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. The effort was a long struggle; Eisenhower had to be convinced that political circumstances had created a genuine duty for him to offer himself as a candidate, and that there was a mandate from the populace for him to be their President. Henry Cabot Lodge, who served as his campaign manager, and others succeeded in convincing him, and in June 1952 he resigned his command at NATO to campaign full-time. Eisenhower defeated Taft for the nomination, having won critical delegate votes from Texas. Eisenhower's campaign was noted for the simple but effective slogan, "I Like Ike". In 2006, Morgan Stanley purchased 20 acres (8.1 ha) directly north of the Showboat Atlantic City Hotel and Casino for a new $2 billion plus casino resort. Revel Entertainment Group was named as the project's developer for the Revel Casino. Revel was hindered with many problems, with the biggest setback to the company being in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, the owner of 90% of Revel Entertainment Group, decided to discontinue funding for continued construction and put its stake in Revel up for sale. Early in 2010 the New Jersey state legislature passed a bill offering tax incentives to attract new investors and complete the job, but a poll by Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind released in March 2010 showed that three of five voters (60%) opposed the legislation, and two of three of those who opposed it "strongly" opposed it. Ultimately, Governor Chris Christie offered Revel $261 million in state tax credits to assist the casino once it opened. As of March 2011[update], Revel had completed all of the exterior work and had continued work on the interior after finally receiving the funding necessary to complete construction. It had a soft opening in April 2012, and was fully open by May 2012. Ten months

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and identity. Most theories on self-esteem state that there is a grand desire, across all genders and ages, to maintain, protect and enhance their self-esteem. Contrary to popular belief, there is no empirical evidence for a significant drop in self-esteem over the course of adolescence. "Barometric self-esteem" fluctuates rapidly and can cause severe distress and anxiety, but baseline self-esteem remains highly stable across adolescence. The validity of global self-esteem scales has been questioned, and many suggest that more specific scales might reveal more about the adolescent experience. Girls are most likely to enjoy high self-esteem when engaged in supportive relationships with friends, the most important function of friendship to them is having someone who can provide social and moral support. When they fail to win friends' approval or couldn't find someone with whom to share common activities and common interests, in these cases, girls suffer from low self-esteem. In contrast, boys are more concerned with establishing and asserting their independence

For its complete North American release, the Nintendo Entertainment System was progressively released over the ensuing years in four different bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set and the Power Set. The Deluxe Set, retailing at US$199.99 (equivalent to $475 in 2016), included R.O.B., a light gun called the NES Zapper, two controllers, and two Game Paks: Gyromite, and Duck Hunt. The Basic Set, retailing at US$89.99 with no game, and US$99.99 bundled with "Super Mario Bros." The Action Set, retailing in 1988 for US$149.99, came with the Control Deck, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak containing both Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt. In 1989, the Power Set included the console, two game controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak containing Super Mario Bros, Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet. In 1990, a Sports Set bundle was released, including the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four game controllers, and a dual Game Pak containing Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. A period of division for the Liberals followed, with former Treasurer John Howard competing with former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock for supremacy. The Australian economy was facing the early 1990s recession. Unemployment reached 11.4% in 1992. Under Dr John Hewson, in November 1991, the opposition launched the 650-page Fightback! policy document − a radical collection of "dry", economic liberal measures including the introduction of a Goods and Services Tax (GST), various changes to Medicare including the abolition of bulk billing for non-concession holders, the introduction of a nine-month limit on unemployment benefits, various changes to industrial relations including the abolition of awards, a $13 billion personal income tax cut directed at middle and upper income earners, $10 billion in government spending cuts, the abolition of state payroll taxes and the privatisation of a large number of government owned enterprises − representing the start of a very different future direction to the keynesian economic conservatism practiced by previous Liberal/National Coalition governments. The 15 percent GST was the centerpiece of the policy document. Through 1992, Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating mounted a campaign against the Fightback package, and particularly against the GST, which he described as an attack on the working class in that it shifted

He sent him, indeed, five hundred pieces of gold "to bear his charges" but Liberius refused them, saying, he might bestow them on his flatters; as he did also a like present from the empress, bidding the messenger learn to believe in Christ, and not to persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the presents in The Church, but Liberius threw them out. The emperor was reduced to silence on every article, but being the more out of patience, ordered him into banishment. Liberius went into exile. Constantius, after two years went to Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The ladies joined in a petition to him that he would restore Liberius. He assented, upon condition that he should comply with the bishops, then, at court. The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory as families started settling into the area. The first schools were subscription schools that typically held in the teacher's home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in Bitterroot valley in 1862. The students were Indian children and the children of Fort Owen employees. The first school term started in early winter and only lasted until February 28. Classes were taught by Mr. Robinson. Another early subscription school was started by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. In this school students were charged $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly had its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, which set the foundations for public schooling. Madison County was the first to take advantage of the newly authorized taxes and it formed fhe first public school in Virginia City in 1886. The first school year was scheduled to begin in January 1866, but severe weather postponed its opening until March. The first school year ran through the summer and didn't end until August 17. One of the first teachers at the school was Sarah Raymond. She was a 25-year-old woman who had traveled to Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. To become a certified teacher, Raymond took a test in her home and paid a $6 fee

On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being replaced by his son Richard. A tragic blow fell upon Burke with the loss of Richard in August 1794, to whom he was tenderly attached, and in whom he saw signs of promise, which were not patent to others and which, in fact, appear to have been non-existent (though this view may have rather reflected the fact that Richard Burke had worked successfully in the early battle for Catholic emancipation). King George III, whose favour he had gained by his attitude on the French Revolution, wished to create him Earl of Beaconsfield, but the death of his son deprived the opportunity of such an honour and all its attractions, so the only award he would accept was a pension of £2,500. Even this modest reward was attacked by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale, to whom Burke replied in his Letter to a Noble Lord (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He argued that he was rewarded on merit, but the Duke of Bedford received his rewards from inheritance

The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500,000 residents fled during this time because of persecution, increased poverty and better economic opportunities in the West or in other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections took place shortly after the end of the war, and Tajikistan was in a state of complete devastation. The estimated dead numbered over 100,000. Around 1.2 million people were refugees inside and outside of the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties under the guidance of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a result widely praised as a successful United Nations peace keeping initiative. The ceasefire guaranteed 30% of ministerial positions would go to the opposition. Elections were held in 1999, though they were criticized by opposition parties and foreign observers as unfair and Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism that has existed at Yale since the 1960s, and the intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many of the future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes the run to Yale’s focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority that began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now president of Duke University, stated: "We do give very significant attention to orientation to the community in our admissions, and there is a very strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale." The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of Portland stone) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. George V, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. The departures of Núñez and van Gaal were hardly noticed by the fans when compared to that of Luís Figo, then club vice-captain. Figo had become a cult hero, and was considered by Catalans to be one of their own. However, Barcelona fans were distraught by Figo's decision to join arch-rivals Real Madrid, and, during subsequent visits to the Camp Nou, Figo was given an extremely hostile reception. Upon his first return, a piglet's head and a full bottle of whiskey were thrown at him from the crowd. The next three years saw the club in decline, and managers came and went. van Gaal was replaced by Llorenç Serra Ferrer who, despite an extensive investment in players in the summer of 2000, presided over a mediocre league campaign and a humiliating first-round Champions League exit, and was eventually dismissed late in the season. Long-serving coach Carles Rexach was appointed as his replacement, initially on a temporary basis, and managed to at least steer the club to the last Champions League spot on the final day of the season. Despite better form in La Liga and a good run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, Rexach was never viewed as a long-term solution and that summer Louis van Gaal returned to the club for a second spell as manager. sampled: In 1954, prominent Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists, and literary critics, supported by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, signed the Novi Sad Agreement, which initially declared: "Serbs, Croats, and Montenegrins share a single language with two equivalent variants developed around Zagreb (western) and Belgrade (eastern)". The agreement emphasized the equal status of Cyrillic and Latin scripts, as well as Ekavian and Ijekavian pronunciations. It stipulated that Serbo-Croatian would be the official language name, while traditional Serbian and Croatian would remain in informal use. Matica hrvatska and Matica srpska committed to collaborating on a dictionary, and a joint committee of Serbian and Croatian linguists was tasked with preparing a pravopis. During the 1960s, both publications were released simultaneously in Ijekavian Latin in Zagreb and Ekavian Cyrillic in Novi Sad. However, Croatian linguists viewed this as an act of unitarianism. Their evidence was somewhat inconsistent: Stjepan Babić complained about Belgrade television's consistent use of Latin script, which, while true, did not necessarily indicate unequal rights but rather reflected usage patterns and prestige. Babić also criticized the Novi Sad Dictionary (1967) for listing variant words side by side, which could be seen as careful respect for both variants rather than unitarism. Interestingly, Croatian linguists critiqued the unitaristic aspects of the Dictionary written by their own compatriots and overlooked the fact that the Pravopisni rječnik's material originated from the Croatian Philological Society. Despite these nuances, Croatian intellectuals issued the Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language in 1967. Forty-five years later, in 2012, the Croatian weekly journal Forum republished the Declaration with a critical analysis.

The Bush administration shifted focus to Iraq, asserting the urgent need to remove Saddam Hussein from power. The primary justification centered on allegations that Hussein's regime had attempted to acquire nuclear materials and failed to provide a comprehensive account of biological and chemical weapons previously in its possession. The administration claimed that both the possession of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) and the inability to account for them would constitute a violation of UN sanctions. Despite the Bush administration's aggressive promotion of the WMD claim, major global powers like China, France, Germany, and Russia remained unconvinced of Iraq's threat and opposed UN Security Council authorization for military action. In November 2002, Iraq allowed UN weapon inspectors to enter, who were conducting investigations when the Bush administration decided to launch the war without UN approval, ordering the inspectors to leave. On March 20, 2003, the United States invaded Iraq with a "coalition of the willing," primarily comprising troops from the United Kingdom, Australia, and Poland. Within approximately three weeks, the invasion toppled the Iraqi government and military, but no weapons of mass destruction were discovered. While traces of former weapons facilities were reported, no conclusive evidence emerged. On May 1, President George W. Bush dramatically landed on the USS Abraham Lincoln and declared an end to "major combat operations." Initially enjoying a 66% approval rating, Bush's public support gradually eroded as the reconstruction efforts stalled, violence persisted, and the absence of WMD stockpiles raised serious questions about the war's original justification.

The environment significantly influences an adolescent's identity formation. While research predominantly focuses on white, middle-class youth, evidence indicates that privileged backgrounds correlate with more successful identity development. The adolescent identity-building phase is a critical life stage. Recent demographic trends reveal that the transition to adulthood now spans a longer period compared to mid-20th century patterns. Consequently, youth—encompassing late adolescence and early adulthood—has emerged as a more significant life phase. This shift has highlighted numerous contributing factors to social identity development, including commitment, coping mechanisms, and social media. An adolescent's environment profoundly shapes these developmental elements. Those from more advantaged backgrounds typically encounter broader opportunities and more positive circumstances. Conversely, adolescents from challenging urban or high-crime neighborhoods may face environments that potentially hinder their personal growth. Adolescence represents a sensitive developmental period where exposure to negative influences can substantially impact future life choices. In contrast, teenagers from affluent suburban communities are more likely to engage in identity-enhancing activities, fostering a more robust and positive self-concept.

The National Football League's preseason stands out for its highly organized structure compared to other team sports. Each NFL team plays precisely four preseason exhibition games annually, with two home and two away matches, except for two teams participating in a fifth game—the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These August exhibitions primarily serve to help coaches reduce their roster from 90 offseason players to the 53-player regular-season limit. While preseason game scheduling is less rigid than regular-season matchups, numerous restrictions and traditions limit opponent selection, and specific days and times for games are constrained. Unlike baseball and hockey, split-squad games are not permitted. The NFL has hosted exhibition games internationally in Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico to expand league popularity, with a proposed Chinese game ultimately canceled due to financial and logistical challenges. The league has effectively banned non-NFL opponent games, with the last interleague match occurring in 1972 and the final game against non-NFL teams (College All-Stars) held in 1976. Many fans find these exhibitions unpopular, resenting season-ticket packages that require full-price payment for two home preseason games. Multiple fan lawsuits challenging this practice have been unsuccessful. The Pro Bowl, now played the week before the Super Bowl, is also considered an exhibition game.

In reality, not every rule infraction leads to a disqualification, as referees have discretionary power and are not required to halt the match. Typically, only specific offenses like low blows, weapon use, outside interference, or attacking the referee will prompt an immediate disqualification. In WWE, a referee must personally witness the violation to end the match, with video evidence rarely sufficing, and their decision is almost always definitive, though Dusty finishes can result in the ruling being overturned. Referee knockouts during matches are common, known as a "ref bump", during which wrestlers can freely break rules until the official is revived or replaced. Sometimes, a referee might disqualify a wrestler presuming they caused the knockout, though most such incidents are strategically planned to give a wrestler, often a heel, an advantage. For instance, a wrestler might intentionally be whipped into a referee at a controlled speed, temporarily incapacitating them. During this brief window, a wrestler could potentially pin their opponent for a three-count and seemingly win, though the fallen referee prevents an official count. Occasionally, another referee might rush from backstage to make the count, but by then, the pinned wrestler typically has had enough time to kick out.

In the 15th century, the cathedral underwent architectural modifications with the addition of a dome and extended naves behind the choir, which connected the building to the tower and created a main entrance. Archbishop Luis Alfonso de los Cameros initiated the construction of the main chapel in 1674, adorning its walls with marbles and bronzes in the characteristic Baroque style of the era. At the start of the 18th century, German architect Conrad Rudolphus designed the façade of the main entrance. Two additional doors lead into the transept: one, the Apostles' door, displays pure pointed Gothic architecture from the 14th century, while the other is known as the Paláu door. Later architectural additions to the cathedral's rear diminished its overall height. The 18th-century restoration softened the pointed arches, replaced Gothic columns with Corinthian pillars, and redecorated the walls. The dome lacks a lantern, featuring a plain ceiling pierced by two large side windows. The cathedral contains four chapels on each side, along with additional chapels in the choir, transept, and sanctuary, and houses numerous paintings by prominent artists. A silver reredos originally behind the altar was melted down during the 1808 war to fund military campaigns. Two paintings by Francisco Goya are located in the San Francesco chapel. A small Renaissance chapel built by Calixtus III is situated behind the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament, and adjacent to the cathedral stands the chapel dedicated to Our Lady of the Forsaken.

Early reviews presented a nuanced perspective. While some critics found the show wildly entertaining, others highlighted its underlying musical talent. Entertainment Weekly's Ken Tucker described it as "crazily entertaining" yet "musically inconsequential". The series was variously characterized as a "sadistic musical bake-off" and "a romp in humiliation". Critics also took issue with the show's commercial aspects, with Karla Peterson from The San Diego Union-Tribune describing it as "a conniving multimedia monster" that reflects cultural decadence. The show's controversial decision to have its first season winner perform the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the 9/11 anniversary drew sharp criticism. Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post sarcastically remarked that "The terrorists have won", critiquing both the show's marketing strategy and its voting mechanism. She pointedly noted the irony of allowing millions of young viewers and dedicated phone-voting enthusiasts to transform a significant memorial site into a marketing opportunity, while Fox denied any manipulation of voting results.

During the 1980s, the media's intense fascination with the royal family's personal lives and opinions sparked numerous sensational and often unverified stories in the press. Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, famously instructed his staff to prioritize provocative headlines about the royals, even if the stories lacked factual accuracy. Donald Trelford, writing in The Observer on 21 September 1986, highlighted how the royal narrative had become so sensationalized that the distinction between truth and fiction had become blurred, with newspapers showing little concern for factual verification. The Sunday Times reported on 20 July 1986 that the Queen was concerned about Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, social divisions, high unemployment, riots, the miners' strike, and Thatcher's stance on South African apartheid. While sources like royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal were cited, Shea argued his comments were misinterpreted. Rumors circulated that Thatcher claimed the Queen would support the Social Democratic Party, though Thatcher's biographer John Campbell dismissed this as journalistic fabrication. Despite apparent tensions, Thatcher later expressed personal admiration for the Queen, who subsequently honored Thatcher with membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney also noted Elizabeth's behind-the-scenes role in combating apartheid.

The palace spans 108 by 120 metres, reaching a height of 24 metres, and encompasses over 77,000 m2 of floor space. Its size is smaller compared to other notable royal residences like the Royal Palace of Madrid, Papal Palace in Rome, Louvre in Paris, Hofburg Palace in Vienna, and the Forbidden City. The structure houses 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms, 52 principal bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. The principal rooms are located on the piano nobile behind the west-facing garden façade. The Music Room, with its large bow, serves as the centre of the ornate state rooms, flanked by the Blue and White Drawing Rooms. The Picture Gallery, a 50-metre long, top-lit corridor, connects the state rooms and displays works by Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens, and Vermeer. Adjacent rooms include the Throne Room and Green Drawing Room, which acts as an anteroom to the Throne Room and part of the ceremonial route from the Guard Room at the top of the Grand Staircase. The Guard Room features white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert in Roman costume, set against tapestry-lined walls. These formal rooms are reserved for ceremonial and official events but are open to the public during summer.

To expand and solidify the dynasty's dominion in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally orchestrated military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. He successfully drove out Galdan's invading forces from these territories, which were subsequently integrated into the empire. Galdan was ultimately killed during the Dzungar–Qing War. In 1683, Qing forces accepted Taiwan's surrender from Zheng Keshuang, Koxinga's grandson, who had previously seized the island from Dutch colonists. Zheng Keshuang was granted the title "Duke Haicheng" and incorporated into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners upon moving to Beijing. Several Ming princes, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan, had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan between 1661-1662, residing in the Kingdom of Tungning. The Qing returned the 17 remaining Ming princes to mainland China in 1683, where they lived in exile, their lives spared from execution. Capturing Taiwan enabled Kangxi's forces to engage in battles over Albazin, Russia's far eastern outpost. Zheng's former soldiers, such as the rattan shield troops, were integrated into the Eight Banners and deployed against Russian Cossacks at Albazin. The 1689 Treaty of Nerchinsk, China's first formal agreement with a European power, maintained border peace for nearly two centuries. Following Galdan's death, his Buddhist followers attempted to influence the Dalai Lama's selection, prompting Kangxi to dispatch armies to Lhasa and install a Dalai Lama sympathetic to Qing interests.

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall and his colleagues pioneered an influential intellectual movement that transformed academic understanding of cultural phenomena. The emerging field integrated multiple disciplines, including political economy, sociology, communication, media studies, anthropology, and philosophy, to examine cultural texts and practices. Researchers in this domain often explore how specific phenomena intersect with ideology, social identity, class, and gender dynamics. Cultural studies focuses on the meanings and practices embedded in everyday life, investigating how people engage with various activities and objects within their cultural context. The field is particularly interested in understanding practices that are not necessarily rational but culturally significant, such as social behaviors that emerge from a desire to belong. As global capitalism expanded, cultural studies began examining resistance to Western cultural dominance, recognizing globalization as a process that potentially undermines local cultural integrity. This perspective views globalization as a complex system that can be simultaneously transformative and oppressive, challenging the cultural autonomy of diverse societies worldwide.

Libya's economic landscape increasingly embraced privatization, with government officials claiming to pursue "people's socialism" instead of traditional capitalism, despite moving away from the socialist principles outlined in The Green Book. Gaddafi endorsed these economic reforms, advocating for widespread privatization in a 2003 speech. The oil industry was largely transferred to private corporations, and foreign investment surged to $40 billion by 2004, a sixfold increase from the previous year. Public demonstrations emerged in response to these changes, and in March 2006, revolutionary hard-liners assumed control of the GPC cabinet, moderating the reform pace without completely halting progress. By 2010, plans were proposed to privatize half the Libyan economy over the following decade. While political liberalization remained limited and Gaddafi maintained predominant control, municipal councils received expanded powers in March 2010. Reformist technocrats increasingly gained governance positions, with Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, Gaddafi's son and heir apparent, being the most prominent. He publicly criticized Libya's human rights record, proposed a draft constitution, and was appointed to lead the PSLC in October 2009. Saif established several private media channels in 2008 to promote tourism, but these were nationalized in 2009 after criticizing the government. In October 2010, Gaddafi apologized to African leaders on behalf of Arab nations for their historical involvement in the slave trade.

Mammalian hair, or pelage, exhibits diverse color variations across populations, individual organisms, and even within a single animal. Color differences between light and dark spectrums are prevalent in mammalian groups. These variations can stem from age-related factors or other influences. Ecological interactions, environmental conditions, and selective pressures frequently drive mammalian color diversity, promoting survival through specific color adaptations. Camouflage emerges as the primary mechanism for color variation, enabling organisms to conceal themselves from predators or prey. However, sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes also contribute to color evolution. Coat color serves multiple functions, including intraspecies communication, such as warning signals, health indicators, mother-offspring interactions, and predator deterrence. Research indicates that differences in male and female coat colors can reveal nutritional and hormonal information crucial for mate selection. Physiological responses, like temperature regulation in extreme environments, further explain color variations. Despite extensive observations, the genetic mechanisms linking coat color to specific genes remain partially unknown. Genetic sites responsible for pigmentation are understood to affect phenotype by modifying hair pigmentation distribution and hair density. Quantitative trait mapping helps researchers better comprehend the genetic loci driving pigmentation variation, though significant gaps in understanding gene expression persist.

During the French Enlightenment in the mid-18th century, the term "humanism" began to acquire a more ideological meaning. In 1765, an anonymous author in a French periodical described "the general love of humanity" as a previously unnamed virtue, suggesting the creation of a word for this beautiful and necessary concept. The late 18th and early 19th centuries witnessed the emergence of numerous grassroots philanthropic and benevolent societies focused on human advancement and knowledge dissemination. Following the French Revolution, the notion that human virtue could be generated through reason alone, without traditional religious institutions, was vehemently criticized by conservative religious and political figures like Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, who viewed it as a form of human deification. Consequently, humanism started to carry a negative connotation. The Oxford English Dictionary noted the term's use by an English clergyman in 1812 to describe those believing in Christ's "mere humanity" rather than divine nature. In this polarized environment, where ecclesiastical institutions resisted social and political reforms, liberal reformers embraced humanism as an alternative human-centered philosophy. Anarchist Proudhon characterized it as a "worship, deification of humanity," while Ernest Renan proclaimed in his work that pure humanism would become the future religion, celebrating humanity's life and elevating human experience to a moral value.

In multi-party political systems, no single party typically secures absolute power, leading to collaborative coalition governments. This trend has been prominent in Ireland since the 1980s and is standard in Germany across national, state, and local levels. In Iceland, coalition governments have been the norm since the republic's establishment, typically involving the Independence Party and another party like the Social Democratic Alliance. Similarly, in Ireland since 1989, no party has governed independently, with coalitions exclusively led by either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Coalition governments can potentially facilitate political change more effectively than rigid two-party systems, though this is not always guaranteed. In two-party systems with fundamental policy disagreements, such as the current U.S. political landscape between Democrats and Republicans, policy progression can be significantly hindered. Conversely, coalition governments can also struggle to implement changes, as demonstrated in post-World War II France and Italy. When a single party controls all elective branches, policy transformations can be rapid and substantial, as evidenced by Democratic presidents like Wilson, Roosevelt, and Johnson, and Republican leaders such as Lincoln and Reagan, with Obama briefly experiencing such an advantage between 2009 and 2011.

Emotions drive social interactions and relationships, closely linked to basic physiology, especially stress systems. They are connected to the anti-stress complex and the oxytocin-attachment system, which is crucial for bonding. Emotional temperaments influence social connectedness and fitness in complex social environments (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These characteristics are shared across species and taxa, resulting from genetic transmission. DNA sequences encode information for protein assembly in cells. Zygotes inherit genetic information from parental germ cells, and during speciation, heritable traits that enabled ancestral survival and reproduction are passed down, along with potentially beneficial new traits. In the five million years since human and chimpanzee lineages diverged, only about 1.2% of their genetic material has changed, suggesting that distinguishing characteristics are encoded in this small DNA segment, including behaviors. Researchers studying animal behaviors have primarily identified intraspecific gene-dependent behavioral phenotypes. For instance, in voles, minor genetic variations in a vasopressin receptor gene correspond to significant differences in social organization and mating systems (Hammock & Young 2005). Another example is the FOCP2 gene, involved in neural circuitry for speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005), which differs from chimpanzee versions by only a few mutations and has existed for about 200,000 years, coinciding with modern human emergence (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization form the foundation of emotions.

Various research traditions are increasingly employing the concept of identity to analyze different phenomena. One significant implication emerges in occupational contexts, particularly in stigmatized or "dirty work" environments. Individuals are drawn to or repelled from certain jobs based on how well they align with their preferred organizational self. Some occupations carry inherent stigmas or social perceptions that challenge workers' professional identities. For instance, correctional officers struggle to overcome perceptions of being "glorified maids." Workers in such roles must develop strategies to construct a positive self-image and justify their occupational choices. The process involves managing workplace satisfaction and overall life quality. Creating a favorable sense of self becomes particularly challenging when societal standards label one's work as undesirable. Employees often must navigate complex discourses that question their professional legitimacy. When workers encounter obstacles in transforming their stigmatized work into a source of pride, they may resort to strategies like blaming clients to affirm their professional identity and maintain a sense of personal worth.

Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles provide a critical analysis of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper, challenging the commonly cited 85% genetic diversity figure. They argue that this statistic is misleading because it suggests an uniform distribution of genetic variation across all human populations. Instead, they propose a more nuanced understanding of human population history that recognizes the hierarchical and interconnected nature of human groups. According to their perspective, some populations are ancestral to others, forming paraphyletic groups with complex genetic relationships. The recent African origin theory exemplifies this, showing that non-African populations derive from a limited, non-representative sample of the original African population. Consequently, non-African groups share closer genetic similarities with each other and certain African populations, particularly those from East Africa. The migration out of Africa represented a significant genetic bottleneck, with much of the original African genetic diversity not being transmitted to other populations. This model suggests that genetic diversity progressively diminishes with distance from Africa, with each migration event representing a genetic subset of the parent population. Their research indicates that while a single African population contains approximately 100% of human genetic diversity, a population from New Guinea might only retain about 70%. Despite these variations, Long and Kittles conclude that humans remain genetically homogeneous compared to other mammalian species.

Darwin's book was extensively translated during his lifetime, but translators encountered challenges with concepts and metaphors, often introducing personal biases. While distributing presentation copies in France and Germany, Darwin hoped qualified translators would collaborate with local publishers. He initially welcomed Heinrich Georg Bronn, a distinguished naturalist, but the 1860 German translation incorporated Bronn's own perspectives, including controversial themes Darwin had intentionally excluded. Bronn reinterpreted "favoured races" as "perfected races" and added essays on life's origins and religious implications, influenced by his Naturphilosophie philosophy. After producing a second edition in 1862 based on Darwin's suggestions, Bronn died suddenly. Darwin subsequently worked closely with Julius Victor Carus, who published an improved translation in 1867. French translation attempts initially failed, with Clémence Royer's 1862 version including an introduction promoting social Darwinism and eugenics, along with extensive personal annotations. Despite Darwin's correspondence and attempts to modify subsequent editions, he remained dissatisfied until Edmond Barbier's translation emerged in 1876. Translations proliferated during Darwin's lifetime, including Dutch in 1860, Italian and Russian by 1864, and versions in Swedish, Danish, Polish, Hungarian, Spanish, and Serbian between 1871 and 1878. By 1977, the work had been translated into an additional 18 languages.

Hegel aims to preserve the core principles of German idealism, particularly Kant's view that ethical reasoning transcends finite impulses. In Hegel's framework, a fundamental connection between thought and being must exist for any human observer (subject) to comprehend an external entity (object). Through the concept of "subject-object identity," both subject and object share Spirit as their conceptual inner essence—effectively rendering them identical. However, before Spirit achieves self-realization and advances to Absolute Spirit, the human mind mistakenly perceives observed objects as fundamentally separate or alien. As Hegel describes, "The object is revealed to it [to 'subject'] by [as] something alien, and it does not recognize itself." Self-realization occurs when Hegel, representing Spirit's collective human consciousness, recognizes that every object is essentially himself, since both subject and object are manifestations of Spirit. Upon this self-realization, Spirit becomes Absolute Spirit, transforming the "finite" (human) into the "infinite" (divine), thereby replacing the supernatural theistic concept of God with human self-divinity. As Tucker articulates, Hegelianism represents "a religion of self-worship" where humanity compulsively and ultimately successfully strives to elevate itself to divine status.

The Israelites experienced political sovereignty twice in ancient times, initially during the Biblical judges' era and subsequently throughout the United Monarchy. Following the United Monarchy's decline, the territory split into Israel and Judah. The term "Jew" emerged from the Roman "Judean," referring to inhabitants of the southern Judah kingdom. The transition from "Israelites" to "Jews" is explicitly documented in the Book of Esther from the 4th century BCE, part of the Tanakh's Ketuvim section. In 587 BC, Nebuchadnezzar II of the Neo-Babylonian Empire besieged Jerusalem, demolished the First Temple, and deported Judah's most prominent citizens. By 586 BC, Judah lost its independence, leaving its Jewish population stateless. The Babylonian exile concluded in 539 BCE when the Achaemenid Empire conquered Babylon, and Cyrus the Great permitted exiled Jews to return to Yehud and reconstruct their Temple. The Second Temple was completed in 515 BCE. Yehud province remained peaceful within the Achaemenid Empire until Alexander the Great's conquest around 333 BCE. Jews also experienced political independence during the Hasmonean dynasty (140-37 BCE) and partially under the Herodian dynasty (37 BCE-6 CE). Since the Second Temple's destruction in 70 CE, most Jews have lived in diaspora, frequently experiencing persecution as an ethnic minority in various countries.

During the Tokyo Game Show in September 2012, Sony introduced a new PS3 redesign (CECH-4000) featuring multiple storage configurations. The Super Slim model was available in three variants: a 500 GB version, a 250 GB version (excluding PAL regions), and a 12 GB flash storage model exclusively for PAL regions. The 12 GB version could be upgraded with an official 250 GB hard drive, and a vertical stand was also released. The United Kingdom saw the 500 GB model launch on September 28, 2012, and the 12 GB model on October 12, 2012. In the United States, the PS3 Super Slim was initially released as bundled consoles: the 250 GB model with Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception Game of the Year edition on September 25, 2012, and the 500 GB model with Assassin's Creed III on October 30, 2012. Japan received the black Super Slim model on October 4, 2012, and the white version on November 22, 2012. Compared to the Slim model, the Super Slim was 20 percent smaller and 25 percent lighter, featuring a manual sliding disc cover. The white model launched in the US on January 27, 2013, as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. Japan introduced Garnet Red and Azurite Blue models on February 28, 2013, with the Garnet Red version released in North America on March 12, 2013, as a God of War: Ascension bundle, and the Azurite Blue model as a GameStop exclusive 250 GB version.

In 1919, following the Treaty of Versailles, Strasbourg was returned to France in line with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points" without a public vote. The transfer date was retroactively set on Armistice Day. A referendum in Strasbourg would likely not have favored France, as political parties advocating for Alsatian autonomy or French connection represented only a small fraction of votes in the previous Reichstag and local elections. Alsatian autonomists sympathetic to France had gained significant support in rural areas and smaller towns since the region's annexation by Germany in 1871. The movement originated with the first Reichstag election, with elected representatives known as "les députés protestataires" who, until Bismarck's fall in 1890, were the sole Alsatian deputies demanding the territories' return to France. In the final Reichstag election in Strasbourg and surrounding areas, Social Democrats emerged victorious. As the region's administrative capital, the city was populated by numerous Germans appointed by Berlin's central government and boasted a thriving economy, which might explain the voting disparities between urban and rural areas. After the war, many Germans departed Strasbourg for Germany, with some being denounced by locals or expelled by new authorities. The Saverne Affair remained a vivid memory among Alsatians.

Zhejiang's primary manufacturing sectors encompass electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food processing, and construction materials. The province has developed its distinctive "Zhejiang model" of economic growth, which centers on fostering entrepreneurship, supporting small businesses that are market-responsive, making substantial infrastructure investments, and producing low-cost goods in large quantities for both domestic and international markets. This approach has transformed Zhejiang into one of China's most prosperous provinces, with the "Zhejiang spirit" becoming legendary nationwide. However, economic experts now express concerns about the model's long-term viability, arguing that it is inefficient, places excessive strain on resources and public infrastructure, and limits businesses' potential to advance into more sophisticated and technologically complex industries. The economic center is progressively shifting from North Zhejiang, centered on Hangzhou, to the southeastern region around Wenzhou and Taizhou. In 2009, urban residents' disposable income reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603), with an 8.3% annual real growth, while rural residents' pure income stood at 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), reflecting an 8.1% year-on-year increase. By 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP had grown to 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion), with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, the province's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries were valued at 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion), respectively.

In its early stages, MCA produced discs for various companies like Paramount, Disney, and Warner Bros. Some of these companies added their own branding to the disc jacket to indicate non-MCA ownership. Following the closure of Discovision Associates in early 1982, Universal Studio's videodisc software label, known as MCA Videodisc until 1984, began re-releasing numerous DiscoVision titles. However, many of these reissues, including Battlestar Galactica and Jaws, were time-compressed versions of their original CAV or CLV DiscoVision releases. The CLV re-issue of Jaws notably lacked its original soundtrack, with incidental background music replaced due to licensing costs, a situation that persisted until the THX LaserDisc box set's release in 1995. The Universal/Columbia co-production The Electric Horseman, issued by MCA Disco Vision in both CAV and CLV formats, remains unavailable in any other home video format with its original score intact, with recent DVD releases featuring significant music replacements. Similarly, the MCA release of Universal's Howard the Duck displays only the start credits in widescreen before switching to a 4:3 aspect ratio for the remainder of the film. For an extended period, this was the sole disc-based version of the movie until widescreen DVD formats emerged with additional features. Notably, the LaserDisc release of E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial remains the only format containing the deleted scene featuring Harrison Ford as the school headmaster reprimanding Elliott for releasing frogs in the biology class.

In southeast Europe, agrarian societies emerged in the 7th millennium BC, with one of Europe's earliest farming sites discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, dating to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines have been unearthed in the Balkans from 6000 BC and in Central Europe around 5800 BC (La Hoguette). The Sesklo culture in Thessaly stands among the earliest cultural complexes, which expanded in the Balkans and gave rise to Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. Through cultural diffusion and population migrations, Neolithic traditions spread westward and northward, reaching northwestern Europe by approximately 4500 BC. The Vinča culture potentially developed the earliest writing system, the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn suggests they were likely pictograms and ideograms rather than a fully developed writing form. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture constructed massive settlements in Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine from 5300 to 2300 BC. The Mediterranean islands feature notable megalithic temple complexes, such as Ġgantija on Gozo and Mnajdra in Malta, with the oldest structures dating to around 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni in Paola, Malta, is a unique subterranean sanctuary-turned-necropolis from around 2500 BC, representing the world's only prehistoric underground temple. After 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands experienced depopulation until Bronze Age immigrants arrived, introducing a culture that cremated its dead and established smaller megalithic structures called dolmens. These structures typically feature small chambers covered by large slabs placed on upright stones, believed to have been introduced by a population likely originating from Sicily, as evidenced by the similarity to constructions found on the Mediterranean's largest island.

For Popper, knowledge was objective in two dimensions: being objectively true and possessing an ontological status independent of the knowing subject. He conceptualized three distinct worlds: World One representing the physical realm and physical states; World Two encompassing the mental domain of ideas, thoughts, and perceptions; and World Three embodying the comprehensive body of human knowledge expressed through various forms, manifesting the products of World Two within World One's materials like books, artworks, and compositions. He argued that World Three emerges from individual human contributions similar to how animal paths are created by individual animals, thereby existing and evolving autonomously from individual knowing subjects. Popper believed World Three's influence on individual human minds (World Two) is at least as significant as World One's impact. Consequently, an individual's knowledge derives equally from the cumulative wealth of human knowledge as from direct experiential encounters. This perspective suggests that human knowledge's growth is fundamentally a function of World Three's independent evolutionary process. Despite this innovative framework, many contemporary philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, have been reluctant to embrace Popper's Three World theory, primarily due to its apparent resemblance to mind-body dualism.

In the United Kingdom, the political structure that largely influenced the U.S. Constitution did not adhere to a strict separation of powers. The Westminster system, founded on parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government, positioned Parliament (comprising the Sovereign, House of Lords, and House of Commons) as the supreme legislative authority. The executive branch operated in the monarch's name, as did the judiciary. Typically, the King's Ministers were members of either parliamentary house, and the Government required majority support in the House of Commons. The Lord Chancellor uniquely served as both the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords, demonstrating significant overlap between governmental branches. Despite frequent interdepartmental disagreements, the British governmental system often blurred the lines of power separation. Similarly, some 18th-century U.S. states did not strictly observe this principle. New Jersey's Governor simultaneously held positions in the state's highest court and legislature, while Delaware's President was a Court of Appeals member. Executive council members in Delaware and Pennsylvania also served as judges. Conversely, southern states like Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia explicitly mandated a clear separation of governmental powers.

Ottoman madaris encompassed various branches of study, including calligraphic, oral, and intellectual sciences, but fundamentally functioned as an Islamic centre for spiritual learning. The primary objective of knowledge, especially spiritual sciences, was to attain understanding of God. Religion predominantly determined the significance of each scientific discipline. As İnalcık noted, sciences that supported religion were considered valuable, while those like astrology were deemed undesirable. Although mathematics and logic were part of the curriculum, they were invariably intertwined with religious principles. The Ulema believed that studying logic and mathematics was beneficial as it trained the mind to think correctly and ultimately reveal divine truths. Even philosophy was permitted only insofar as it could validate Islamic doctrines. Consequently, madaris were essentially religious institutions dedicated to Islamic teachings and learning. Despite scholars like Goffman arguing for Ottoman societal tolerance and pluralism, these educational centres were predominantly religious and Islam-centric rather than religiously diverse. This approach mirrored contemporary European practices, where Jewish and Protestant educational systems similarly prioritized religious instruction and values. Ultimately, Ottoman madaris offered a comprehensive educational experience, but their fundamental purpose remained the reinforcement and preservation of Islamic practices and theoretical frameworks.

Thuringia boasts a remarkably varied topography. The far northern region is dominated by the Harz mountains, adjacent to the Goldene Aue, a rich floodplain near Nordhausen centered around the Helme river. The north-west encompasses the Eichsfeld, a rolling and partially wooded area where the Leine river originates. Central and northern Thuringia is characterized by the expansive 3000 km² Thuringian Basin, a level and productive zone surrounding the Unstrut river, encircled by numerous hill ranges including Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich, with smaller hill chains like Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen within its boundaries. South of the Basin lies the region's most significant mountain system, featuring the Thuringian Forest in the north-west, the Thuringian Highland centrally, and the Franconian Forest in the south-east. Predominantly forested, this range includes the Großer Beerberg, Thuringia's highest peak at 983 meters. The south-west transitions to the Werra river valley, separating the Rhön Mountains and Grabfeld plain. Eastern Thuringia, east of the Saale and Loquitz valleys, presents a gradually ascending landscape from flat northern plains to southern mountainous terrain. The Saale and Weiße Elster rivers flow northward, creating densely populated valleys. Between these rivers lie the flat, wooded Holzland in the north, the fertile Orlasenke in the middle, and the Vogtland, a mostly treeless hilly region in the south. The far eastern area, known as Osterland or Altenburger Land along the Pleiße river, is a flat, productive, and densely populated agricultural zone.

During the 14th century, French monarchs aimed to enhance their power by reducing the territorial domains of the nobility. They encountered challenges when attempting to seize English-controlled lands in southern France, which ultimately triggered the Hundred Years' War from 1337 to 1453. In the war's early stages, the English, led by Edward III and his son Edward, the Black Prince, achieved significant victories by winning the battles of Crécy and Poitiers, capturing Calais, and gaining control over substantial French territories. These developments nearly caused the collapse of the French kingdom during the initial war years. The early 15th century saw France again approaching disintegration, but Joan of Arc's military achievements in the late 1420s ultimately led to French victory and the recapture of the final English possessions in southern France by 1453. The conflict exacted a tremendous human cost, with France's population likely reduced by half. Conversely, the war positively impacted English national identity, helping to consolidate local identities into a unified national concept and establishing a distinct English culture separate from French influence. The war also marked the emergence of the English longbow as a dominant military weapon and witnessed the introduction of cannon on the battlefield at Crécy in 1346.

The Jurassic Period spans approximately 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 million years ago. During the early Jurassic, Pangaea fragmented into Laurasia in the north and Gondwana in the south, with the Gulf of Mexico emerging in the rift between North America and the Yucatan Peninsula. The North Atlantic was relatively narrow, while the South Atlantic remained closed until the Cretaceous Period when Gondwana began to separate. The Tethys Sea closed, giving rise to the Neotethys basin. Characterized by warm climates without glaciation, the period lacked polar landmasses and ice caps. Western Europe offers an extensive geological record, with marine sequences revealing a continent largely submerged under shallow tropical seas, including notable sites like the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site and the Holzmaden and Solnhofen lagerstätten. In contrast, North America's Jurassic record is the least comprehensive of the Mesozoic, with limited surface outcrops. The Sundance Sea left marine deposits in parts of the northern United States and Canada, but most exposed sediments are continental, such as the Morrison Formation's alluvial deposits. The mid-Jurassic saw the first of several massive batholiths emplaced in the northern Cordillera, marking the Nevadan orogeny. Significant Jurassic exposures can also be found in Russia, India, South America, Japan, Australasia, and the United Kingdom.

At airports, ground crew perform various tasks around aircraft. A tow tractor moves the aircraft to an airbridge, where a ground power unit is connected to provide electricity while the plane is stationary, since its engines are not generating power. Passengers disembark using the airbridge, with mobile stairs offering additional access to the cabin. A cleaning service thoroughly cleans the aircraft after landing. Flight catering supplies onboard food and drinks. A toilet waste truck removes human waste from the aircraft's holding tank, while a water truck replenishes the water tanks. A fuel transfer vehicle moves aviation fuel from underground tanks to the aircraft. Tractors with dollies transport luggage between the terminal and the aircraft. Hi-loaders lift heavy luggage containers to the cargo hold entrance, where ground crew push them in or out. For awkwardly shaped or late luggage, a conveyor belt truck handles transportation. New passengers board via the airbridge, and the tow tractor then pushes the aircraft to a taxi area. The goal is to have the aircraft off the airport and airborne within 90 minutes, with the airport billing the airline for the time spent on the ground.

The pinnacle of leadership in Islam, the caliphate, was first claimed by Ottoman sultans beginning with Murad I, establishing the Ottoman Caliphate. The Ottoman sultan, known as pâdişâh or "lord of kings", served as the Empire's supreme ruler and embodied its governmental structure, though not always exercising absolute power. The Imperial Harem emerged as a crucial center of influence within the Ottoman court, governed by the Valide Sultan. Occasionally, the Valide Sultan would intervene in state affairs, leading to a period when women effectively controlled the government, termed the "Sultanate of Women". Succession was strictly hereditary, with new sultans always selected from the sons of the previous ruler. The palace school's rigorous system aimed to identify suitable heirs and secure support from ruling elites. The educational institutions were divided into two primary tracks: the Madrasa, dedicated to Muslim education and training scholars and state officials according to Islamic traditions, supported by vakifs that enabled social mobility for children from poor families; and the Enderûn, a free boarding school for Christians that annually recruited 3,000 students aged eight to twenty through the Devshirme process, selecting one boy from every forty families in Rumelia and the Balkan communities.

After obtaining the Master Sword, Link is freed from the wolf-transforming magic and gains the Shadow Crystal, allowing him to switch between forms at will. Midna guides him to the Mirror of Twilight in the Gerudo Desert, the sole known passage between the Twilight Realm and Hyrule. They discover the mirror is fragmented, and the Sages explain that Zant could only shatter it, as only the true ruler of the Twili can completely destroy it. The Sages reveal they previously used the mirror to banish Ganondorf, the Gerudo leader who attempted to steal the Triforce, after failing to execute him. With help from an underground resistance in Castle Town, Link and Midna retrieve the mirror's shards by defeating those infected. Upon restoring the portal, Midna is revealed as the true Twilight Realm ruler, whom Zant had usurped and cursed. When confronting Zant, they learn he made his coup possible by forming a pact with Ganondorf, who sought Zant's help in conquering Hyrule. After Link defeats Zant, Midna recovers the Fused Shadows and destroys Zant, realizing only Ganondorf's death can break her curse. Returning to Hyrule, they find Ganondorf in the castle with Zelda suspended lifeless above him. Ganondorf battles Link by possessing Zelda and later transforming into a beast, but Link ultimately defeats him, allowing Midna to resurrect Zelda.

Jerusalem holds profound religious significance for Jews, Muslims, and Christians, housing crucial sacred sites within its Old City, including the Western Wall, Temple Mount, Al-Aqsa Mosque, and Church of the Holy Sepulchre. Israel contains numerous other religiously important locations, such as Nazareth (significant in Christianity as Mary's Annunciation site), Tiberias and Safed (two of Judaism's Four Holy Cities), the White Mosque in Ramla (an Islamic shrine of Prophet Saleh), and the Church of Saint George in Lod (revered in both Christianity and Islam as Saint George's tomb). The West Bank also hosts significant religious landmarks, including Joseph's Tomb in Nablus, Jesus's birthplace, Rachel's Tomb in Bethlehem, and the Cave of the Patriarchs in Hebron. Haifa serves as the Bahá'í Faith's administrative center, housing the Shrine of the Báb, with the faith's leader buried in Acre. Despite having no permanent Bahá'í community beyond maintenance staff, the location remains a pilgrimage destination, with staff strictly prohibited from proselytizing to Israelis. Nearby, the Middle East centre of the Ahmadiyya movement exists in a unique mixed neighborhood of Jews and Ahmadi Arabs, representing the country's sole such community.

Notre Dame underwent significant conference realignment in July 2013, affecting most of its sports except football and fencing, with fencing's affiliation set to change in July 2014. The university departed from the Big East for the ACC during a period of conference instability, maintaining football independence while committing to play five annual games against ACC opponents. In ice hockey, the team was compelled to seek a new conference following the Big Ten's decision to add the sport, which ultimately led to the Central Collegiate Hockey Association's dissolution after the 2012–13 season. Consequently, Notre Dame transferred its hockey program to Hockey East. Upon joining the ACC, the conference announced it would introduce fencing as a sponsored sport starting in the 2014–15 academic year. The Fighting Irish nickname, used for the football team since the early 1920s, was popularized by alumnus Francis Wallace through his New York Daily News columns. Navy Blue and Gold Rush serve as the official team colors, with green often incorporated due to the Fighting Irish moniker. The Notre Dame Leprechaun, designed by Theodore W. Drake in 1964, initially appeared on the football pocket schedule and program covers, and gained national recognition after being featured on the cover of Time in November 1964.

In 1718, responding to a request from either Rector Samuel Andrew or Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather reached out to Elihu Yale, a prosperous businessman residing in Wales who was originally from Boston and whose father was among New Haven's first settlers, seeking financial assistance for constructing a new college building. Persuaded by Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had amassed wealth trading in Madras as an East India Company representative, donated nine bales of goods that were sold for over £560, a considerable amount at the time. Cotton Mather proposed renaming the institution Yale College. Concurrently, a Harvard alumnus working in England convinced approximately 180 distinguished intellectuals to contribute books to Yale. The 1714 book shipment of 500 volumes represented the pinnacle of contemporary English literature, science, philosophy, and theology, profoundly influencing Yale's intellectuals. Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards discovered John Locke's writings and developed his groundbreaking "new divinity" theology. In 1722, the Rector and six colleagues from their study group announced their departure from Calvinism, embracing Arminianism and joining the Church of England. They were ordained in England and returned to the colonies as Anglican missionaries. Thomas Clapp became president in 1745 and endeavored to restore the college's Calvinist orthodoxy while preserving the library, where students continued to discover Deist literature.

Despite attempts to revive Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people, proficiency in the language remains limited among Jews globally, with English becoming the primary communication medium for the Jewish diaspora. While many Jews historically possessed sufficient Hebrew knowledge to engage with classical literature, and Jewish languages like Yiddish and Ladino were prevalent in the early 20th century, most Jews today lack such linguistic capabilities, with English largely replacing traditional Jewish vernaculars. Hebrew, English, and Russian currently represent the most widely spoken languages among Jews, with Romance languages such as French and Spanish also being commonly used. Historically, Yiddish has been the most spoken Jewish language, but its usage has significantly declined following the Holocaust and the emergence of Modern Hebrew through the Zionist movement and the establishment of Israel. In certain regions, the Jewish community's primary language differs from the dominant local language. For instance, Quebec's Ashkenazic majority uses English, while the Sephardic minority predominantly speaks French, and South African Jews have adopted English over Afrikaans. Czarist and Soviet policies have transformed Russian into the primary language for Jewish communities in post-Soviet states like Ukraine and Uzbekistan, as well as for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Although North African Jewish communities have diminished, they previously transitioned to predominantly French-speaking populations in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunis, while the broader population continues to use Arabic.

Galicia's human habitation dates back to the Middle Paleolithic period, deriving its name from the Gallaeci, Celtic peoples inhabiting the region north of the Douro river during the last millennium BC, an area largely corresponding to the Iron Age Castro culture. The Romans incorporated Galicia following the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, establishing it as a province in the 3rd century AD. In 410, the Germanic Suebi founded a kingdom centered in Braga, which was later absorbed by the Visigoth kingdom in 585. The Arab invasion of the Iberian Peninsula in 711 overthrew the Visigoth realm, but by 740, Galicia had been integrated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias. Throughout the Middle Ages, Galicia alternated between independent rule and alliance with the kingdoms of Leon and Castile, while preserving its distinct legal and cultural identity. From the 13th century, Castilian monarchs appointed an Adiantado-mór, whose role evolved into the Governor and Captain General of Galicia by the late 15th century. This Governor also presided over the Royal Audiencia, a governmental tribunal. The kingdom's representation was maintained through the Cortes, an assembly of city deputies, until 1833 when the region was divided into four administrative provinces. The 19th and 20th centuries saw growing demands for self-governance and recognition of Galicia's unique character, culminating in the unsuccessful 1936 Autonomy Statute and the currently operative 1981 Autonomy Statute.

Birds possess an exceptionally efficient oxygen diffusion system, with a gas exchange surface area ten times greater than mammals. Consequently, birds have a higher blood concentration in their capillaries relative to lung volume compared to mammals. The arteries feature thick, elastic muscles designed to endure ventricular constriction, becoming increasingly rigid as they extend from the heart. Blood traverses through arteries undergoing vasoconstriction and enters arterioles, which serve as a transportation network primarily distributing oxygen and nutrients to bodily tissues. As arterioles branch further from the heart and penetrate individual organs, they subdivide to enhance surface area and decelerate blood flow. Progressing through arterioles, blood enters capillaries where gas exchange occurs. These capillaries form organized beds within tissues, facilitating the exchange of oxygen for carbon dioxide waste. Blood flow in capillary beds is deliberately slowed to maximize oxygen diffusion into tissues. After becoming deoxygenated, blood moves through venules and veins back to the heart. Unlike arteries, veins are thin and less rigid due to reduced pressure requirements. During transit through venules to veins, vasodilation funnels blood homeward. Upon reaching the heart, blood first enters the right atrium, then the right ventricle, where it is pumped through the lungs for carbon dioxide and oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood subsequently flows from the lungs through the left atrium to the left ventricle, from which it is pumped throughout the body.

Roc-A-Fella released The College Dropout in February 2004, which quickly climbed to number two on the Billboard 200, with his debut single "Through the Wire" holding steady at number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 for five weeks. His second single, "Slow Jamz", featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, became an even more significant hit, securing the trio's first number one track. The album received widespread critical praise, being named the top album of the year by two major music publications and consistently ranked among the most influential hip-hop debut albums. "Jesus Walks", the album's fourth single, potentially expanded West's audience by exploring themes of faith and Christianity, surprisingly reaching the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts despite industry skepticism about its religious content. The College Dropout ultimately achieved triple platinum certification in the US and earned West 10 Grammy nominations, including Album of the Year and Best Rap Album, which he won. During this period, West also established GOOD Music, a record label and management company that would support various artists and producers like No I.D. and John Legend. Initially known for using sped-up vocal samples from soul records, West began to shift his production style due to the technique's widespread imitation and his desire to explore new musical directions.

As predicted by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet appeared near Midway on 4 June and was detected by PBY patrol planes. Nagumo launched an initial assault on Midway, while Fletcher dispatched his aircraft toward Nagumo's carriers. At 09:20, the first U.S. carrier aircraft, TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from Hornet, arrived but their attacks were uncoordinated and ineffective; hampered by defective aerial torpedoes, they failed to inflict any damage and were completely destroyed by defending Zero fighters. At 09:35, an additional 15 TBDs from Enterprise attacked, with 14 being shot down and no successful hits. Although Fletcher's attacks seemed disorganized and futile, they successfully drew Nagumo's defensive fighters to sea level, causing them to expend significant fuel and ammunition repelling the two torpedo bomber waves. Consequently, when U.S. dive bombers appeared at high altitude, the Zeros were poorly positioned to defend. Furthermore, Nagumo's four carriers had dispersed while attempting to evade torpedoes, which reduced their anti-aircraft fire's concentration. Nagumo's hesitation also generated confusion among his carriers. Aware of the need for a second Midway strike but concerned about the American carriers now in the area, Nagumo repeatedly changed his aircraft arming instructions. As a result, American dive bombers found the Japanese carriers with decks cluttered with munitions as crews frantically worked to re-arm their air groups.

Vladimir was the prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972. In 976, he was compelled to escape to Scandinavia after his half-brother Yaropolk murdered Oleg and seized control of Rus. With assistance from his relative Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, the ruler of Norway, Vladimir gathered a Viking army and successfully reclaimed Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk. As the Prince of Kiev, his most significant accomplishment was the Christianization of Kievan Rus', which commenced in 988. According to the Primary Chronicle, when Vladimir decided to abandon the traditional Slavic idol-worship, he dispatched his most trusted advisors and warriors as emissaries across Europe. These representatives visited Christian, Jewish, and Muslim communities before reaching Constantinople. They dismissed Islam due to its alcohol prohibition and rejected Judaism because of the historical dispossession of the Jewish people. Finding the Roman church ceremonies unimpressive, they were profoundly moved by the Hagia Sophia's magnificence and the Byzantine liturgical service. Upon returning, they persuaded Vladimir that the Byzantine Rite was superior. Consequently, Vladimir traveled to Constantinople and arranged a marriage with Princess Anna, the sister of Byzantine emperor Basil II.

Identity development is a crucial phase in the adolescent life cycle. Most individuals begin their search for identity during these formative years.
